clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Mobilization on Acute Postoperative Pain and Nociceptive Function
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Mobilization on Acute Postoperative Pain and Nociceptive Function After Total Knee Arthroplasty: A Prospective, Consecutive, Trial

brief_summary.textblock:
Aim of the present study is twofold.
- First we want to evaluate the effect of mobilization on acute postoperative pain
- Second to test weather chances in pain sensitivity are occurring following surgery and mobilization after total knee arthroplasty

detailed_description.textblock:
Little is known about the effect of mobilization on acute postoperative pain and mobilization induced pain, and if altered pain sensitivity occur under these circumstances.
- First we want to evaluate the effect of mobilization on acute postoperative pain using the visual analog scale (VAS)
- Second to test weather chances in pain sensitivity are occurring following surgery and mobilization after total knee arthroplasty, using two simple tools, the Pain Matcher and a Pressure Algometer.

primary_outcome.measure: Pain score on the visual analog scale (difference before and after two mobilisation seances)
primary_outcome.description: pain at rest (supine) 5 min after exercise(after the 2nd walk)

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain score on the visual analog scale (difference before and after two mobilisation seances)
secondary_outcome.description: pain at rest (supine) 20 min after the 2nd walk, pain during passive hip flexion and pain during passive knee flexion 5 and 20 min after the 2nd walk, as well as pain during the 2nd walk after 6 and 25 m

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain sensitivity measured with pressure algometry and with pain matcher (difference before and after two mobilisation seances and difference before and after surgery)
secondary_outcome.description: Nociceptive function before and after postoperative exercise

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients scheduled for total unilateral knee arthroplasty
Exclusion Criteria:
- Cognitive dysfunction or peripheral / central neurological dysfunction inconsistent with protocol completing
- Alcohol and medical abuse (as defined by the National Health Service of Denmark
- Daily use of opioids or glucocorticoids
